issue.title: operator>>(basic_istream&, CharT*) makes it hard to avoid buffer overflows

discussion.p:
We removed gets() (due to an NB comment and C11 — bastion of backwards compatibility — doing the same). Should we remove this too?
Unlike gets(), there are legitimate uses:

… but the risk from constructs like "std::cin >> buffer" seems to outweigh the benefit.
The issue had been discussed on the library reflector starting around c++std-lib-35541.
VV: Request a paper to deprecate / remove anything
STL: This overload is evil and should probably die.
VV: I agree with that, even though I don't care.
STL: Say that we either remove it outright following the gets() rationale, or at least deprecate it.
Move to Open; needs a paper.
discussion.note: 2016-08, Chicago: Zhihao Yuan comments and provides wording

li.p: I would like to keep some reasonable code working;
For a), banning bad code will become a silent behavior change at runtime; for b), it breaks at compile time.

discussion.p: I propose to replace these signatures with references to arrays. An implementation may want to ship the old instantiatations in the binary without exposing the old signatures.
Tues PM: General agreement on deprecating the unsafe call, but no consensus for the P/R.
General feeling that implementation experience would be useful.
Will be resolved by the adoption of P0487.
discussion.note: 2018-11-11 Resolved by P0487R1, adopted in San Diego.

blockquote.p: -7- Effects: Behaves like a formatted input member (as described in ) of in. After a sentry object is constructed, operator>> extracts characters and stores them into successive locations of an array whose first element is designated by s. If width() is greater than zero, n is width()min(size_t(width()), N). Otherwise n is the number of elements of the largest array of char_type that can store a terminating charT()N. n is the maximum number of characters stored.
